items.quote:
Es un excelente juego, mejora en todos los aspectos a breath of the wild, si bien el mundo ciertamente es el mismo, es mucho más grande, tenemos el cielo con sus islas flotantes, y el subsuelo que sigue siendo una gran extensión de tierra para explorar, gráficamente tiene una ligera mejora respecto a breath of the wild, sobre todo en la iluminación, la banda sonora a mi parecer también mejoro, al explorar tenemos temas un poco más variados que solo las 3 notas de piano del juego pasado.
Jugablemente ni que decir, es mucho más superior que breath of the wild, nos permite explorar el mundo de mil maneras diferentes, y con respecto a la dificultad, tuvo un aumento, no monstruoso al grado de decir que es un dark souls, pero ciertamente es algo más difícil que breath of the wild y eso se agradece, los enemigos son más fuertes, hay más variedad de ellos y podría jurar que la inteligencia artificial fue mejorada.
Solo le veo 2 detalles, uno de estos "detalles" entre comillas, es que la estructura en si, es prácticamente la misma que el juego pasado, partimos de una zona delimitada en la que hay que completar varios santuarios para obtener acceso al mundo abierto, y al llegar a el partimos de la premisa de que hay que visitar las 4 regiones que ya vimos en el juego pasado, si bien en mi opinión esto no es un problema muy grande, ya que hablamos que es su secuela directa, si que podría resultar repetitivo para algunos.
Y el último detalle que si considero un problema, es el rendimiento, dios, en general es bueno, casi siempre se mantienen los 30fps, pero hay momentos donde puede llegar a caer a los 20, y ni siquiera son momentos donde hay mucha acción, por ejemplo en la aldea kakariko, el juego en ocasiones baja de esos 30 fps, o en zonas abiertas donde usamos la ultramano también llega a bajar en ocasiones, y no se si sea cuestión de mi switch, pero por momentos hace bastante ruido, solo en el modo tv, no al punto de oirse como turbina de avión pero si te acercas es notorio, la switch es una gran consola y ha tenido ports muy buenos, pero con tears of the kingdom, me parece que ya pide su jubilación a gritos.
Es un excelente juego, probablemente Goty, pero el rendimiento si deja bastante que desear.

items.quote:
The Legend of Zelda series has always been a beacon of innovation and storytelling in the gaming world. With "Tears of the Kingdom," the franchise has once again outdone itself, proving that there's always room for growth and evolution, even in a series as storied as this one.

Compared to its predecessor, "Tears of the Kingdom" is a treasure trove of depth and richness. The main quest itself is a sprawling epic, filled with intricate narratives, challenging puzzles, and memorable characters. But where the game truly shines is in its side adventures and dungeons. In the previous installment, many felt that there was a noticeable lack of these elements, which are quintessential to the Zelda experience. Thankfully, the developers took this feedback to heart. The new dungeons are not only numerous but also varied, each offering a unique challenge and story. The side quests, meanwhile, are as engaging as the main storyline, often intertwining with it in unexpected ways.

Exploration in "Tears of the Kingdom" is unparalleled. The vast, open world is brimming with secrets waiting to be discovered, from hidden villages to ancient ruins. Every nook and cranny feels purposeful, and the sense of wonder never diminishes, no matter how many hours you pour into the game.

One of the standout features of this installment is the introduction of new gameplay mechanics. These fresh additions breathe new life into the series, ensuring that even long-time fans will find something novel to enjoy. Without giving away any spoilers, players can expect to be pleasantly surprised and challenged in new ways.

In conclusion, "The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom" is a masterclass in game design and storytelling. While it pays homage to its roots, it's not afraid to chart new territories. With its deep quests, expansive world, and innovative gameplay, it's no wonder it has earned a well-deserved 9 out of 10. Whether you're a seasoned Zelda veteran or a newcomer to the series, this game is a must-play.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
I can't remember the a time I complained about a game nearly the entire time I played it, yet left the experience loving it so much, but The Legend of Zelda Tears of the Kingdom currently has the honor of being that experience for me. Everything about this game is familiar to it's predecessor Breath of the Wild, but harder. The enemies hurt more, the weapons are weaker, the guidance is vaguer, the side quests are more convoluted, and everything about it reminds me how much I love the first game more... And yet somehow, that made this title stand out in a way that made it so unique. It's so different as a successor with so many new and unique mechanics that changed up the gameplay experience, and that created a new level of fun in it's own right (and plenty of frustration, but still lots of fun).

Breath of the Wild had a clear focus on exploration, and a world to explore and secrets to uncover. That charm is missing here, with the same world as the first game and a more desolate one at that. Instead where the charm of Tears of the Kingdom comes in is expanding on that world. Revisiting characters from the first game was an honest joy that made me happy to see some old favorites again, which was the case both in main quests as well as the side adventures that all tell their own charming stories. Story is the clear focus of this game, reusing old favorites like Zelda, Purah and the friends Link made in each regions, but also adding new characters to deepen the lore like Rauru, Sonia, and of course Ganondorf. How this game expanded on it's world and characters was done not by giving us new things to see, but more to do in the places we've already seen. Apart of me almost wishes you started the game with the surface map unlocked for this very reason. This game is the true definition of a sequel in every sense of the word.

I could go on for paragraphs over what makes Tears of the Kingdom so special, but honestly it has a magic that has to be found on it's own. This game can be punishing, even grueling at times. Full completion feels nearly impossible, and with such a well done story, you may find yourself just wanting to cross the finish line rather than stop to smell the roses. But for every complaint I could have, I could go on about something I loved about the experience. Tears of the Kingdom may not be a perfect game, but it was an amazing one that I will never forget, and would happily revisit again.

There is nothing to this story.  It keeps you on the the edge of your seat each memory and flashback you find all to culminate into elementary story writing.

Even worse they completely diminished Ganondorfs character.

Decades of building up this villain to bring him back and turn him into a clown at the end of the game.

If I was going to let my bias for my love of the original Ganondorf really show here I would have given the game a 0.

But I digress. 
You’ll have your 100+ hours of fun out of this game but definitely one of the worst of the mainstream releases.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
A great adventure game, but a completionists nightmare

Tears of the Kingdom is a fantastic game if you're looking for a 60-hour experience, but if you set yourself completionist goals, for example discovering all shrines, the flaws of this game weigh in heavily, since the game then easily reaches the 200-hour mark.

These being:
- The horrible controls (not remappable)
- The recycled and way too small soundtrack
- The grind; 100,000 rupees to upgrade all armor sets while a quest rewards an average of 20- Enemy Sponges
- The repetitive weapon fusing- The Ultrahand vehicle puzzles

I recommend this game to any fan of exploration games, but do not plan to complete it to 100%.

items.quote:
I've experiences BOTW and it was a good game with a first open world experience on switch but It start to be boring after a certain amount of time, I was always running, climbing, cooking more than to resolve enigma or enjoying the game play. I was also frustrated with the weapons durability because you always keep you best weapons apart because "we never know" and I was not really enjoying the game as much as I wanted. 

TOTK is incredible because I was still sceptic but my twin sister was convinced I will enjoy it so that became my birth gift. And..
I really enjoy the new game play, some times you just play to create, or try crazing stuff with your new abilities. I love the fact that the world is not just flat, so you just can't discover everything at the top of a tower, you need to go up and down, I love this relief. I prefer by far the sanctuaries here than in BOTW, most focus on our new ability and master our gameplay. Finally, all these little touches makes the game a bit less predictable and it's for me the strongest asset of this Zelda compared to BOTW.

When you have to create a master piece after a master piece it is almost impossible to surprise and create a game as great as the previous game but they did. It will always be the second Zelda ranked game on the switch because BOTW has a particular meaning for people, but for me it is sincerely the best.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote: Zelda Tears of the Kingdom is a masterpiece! So much so Xbox, Sony and people from Steam had to congratulate Nintendo publicly for it. It again does what systems that boas of power and technology marvel can’t even do.      Link is exploring Hyrule again but it’s not the same as last time! There is now sky portions and also the depths (beneath the ground) portion! I explained it to a friend and he was like. “Oh shoot! So you go to hell?!” I cracked up so hard!!! I told him no you don’t go to hell but you’re deep underground and becasue there is lava in certain parts it’s kind of like hell. lol!      Not only that but there are new sages of the elements to help Link and not just with a little measly attack like the last ones. There aren’t any divine beats this time but you can take avatars of those elemental sages with you all at once in Hyrule!      Yes that’s right you can literally go around with your own mob and mob on the moblins and other monsters for a change! This was a breath of fresh air for me to see Link not alone all the time. There are the usual weapons and items you can collect on your own or buy from vendors.      There is so much to do and I know I didn’t do everything, but the dungeons are absolutely amazing!      They all have a theme song but the theme changes depending on what stage of the dungeon you’re at. So basically every dungeon actually has about 5 different songs to it. There are 4 main dungeons so that’s 20 songs. They way they blend it with the story is incredible and it’s so fitting not intruding on the gameplay at all like many AAA games seem to like to do.      No area is off limits and you aren’t penalized for going out of bounds or some other silly crap like that. If anyone wants to make any game open world or not, you should definitely take notes from Zelda TOTK.      Wherever you see you can go. One of the new features this time around are the being below and going above through the earth. This power is great and definitely makes scaling certain areas they you may remember in Zelda Breath of the Wild much more easy now. The upheaval happened and due to that there are more caves than ever in Hyrule. Use that to your advantage!      The depths are great for finding a new raw mineral called Zoneite. This is integral if you want to use the newly descovered ancient tech.     To top it all off you know who is the last boss. The big bad! He’s back in full force this time not just as some ethereal mad being but as the man the myth and the legend that is Ganon/Ganondorf! He’s everything you’d expect from a top tier villain, and depending on how you played the game it can be more or less challenging leading up to him.      Nintendo once again outdoes themselves and pushes the hardware to the max with this one, continuing to set the standard for games anywhere and  everywhere.      I give Zelda TOTK a 11/10, and it greatly exceeds my expectations so much! It’s packed with content! An absolute must buy! I recommend it to everyone! Love and peace! happy gaming everyone!

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote: Tears of the Kingdom is an excellent if imperfect game that doubles down on the Breath of the Wild formula instead of reinventing it. It pushes and expands it as far as it can go on the Switch, stuffing open world Hyrule with a Lego universe of movable and buildable objects, adding a new dimension of sky islands and underground labyrinths, and creating more complex bosses and temples than BotW. When the game fires on all cylinders, it really fires: Some of the set-piece boss encounters, especially the epic finale with Ganondorf, are superb. And the new building powers are tastefully handled, coaxing you into using them at your leisure rather than forcing you into anything (apart from one pretty painful robot mission). But overall there are fewer moments of wonder and more busywork than in BotW. And there was less reason to hang around up in the sky or explore the depths than I’d hoped. More of the same is no bad thing when it’s Zelda, and overall this is a worthy sequel. But when the credits rolled I felt ready to move on from this chapter of Hyrule.

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
I think my score gets extra points because i didn't play botw. For me, the exploration was a new thing in Zelda games, i don't know if it felt the same for players who played both totk and botw. Overall this game is awesome, but has a few major let downs. 
 
The dungeons are really boring compared to older Zelda titles. In totk all dungeons are based on one idea, go to four or five different places and then fight the boss. At least the last dungeon has more character.
 
Also the story doesn't go anywhere while you complete the main four dungeons around Hyrule. After each dungeon you get almost exactly the same cut scene every time, about the imprisoning war. It is one of the most boring ways for a game to tell a story.

This review turned out to be way more negative then i wanted. I still love the game. The ending is really epic and overall i think the game was best after the four temples.

The gameplay and exploration is really fun, sometimes i played the game for like 5 hours without noticing. The abilities were really fun and creative. My favourite has to be ascend. It makes coming out from caves so much easier. The Zonai devices was a really cool addition as well. Building vehicles was fun and a really easy way of exploring the depths.

My score still remains a 9 even though the game has it's flaws. It might not be my favourite Zelda game, but it still was an epic and fun journey!

items.quote: The more I play this game, the less I like it. Every single aspect of the game is designed to take as much time as possible. Slow un-engaging text boxes, slow unskippable animations that you have to watch over and over, slow menus. Plus slow movement and overcomplicated controls. So, so, so much loading. Over half the game is just waiting for the game to let you continue. When I complete a quest I feel punished because it just means I have to waste more time waiting for dialog or cutscenes. You can step back and say "well they technically added a lot", but none of it feels new, fresh, or special. It's a bunch of padding designed to waste as much time as possible to block you from getting to the better content. The main overworld map is copy-pasted from BOTW. The underworld map is copy-pasted from the overworld map. The sky islands are just frustrating to navigate, in general. Worst of all, the game keeps trying to force me to build a car, and I 100% do not want to build a car; Especially not when the car takes about 5 minutes to build and 20 seconds to break. It always costs more time than it saves, but they force you to do it.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
If you played BotW, don’t get this game because you’ve already played it. This game has its origins as BotW DLC and it shows - it’s messed right up that they charge a whopping $70 for 4 extra gigs of poor game design. If you didn’t play BotW, you’re clear.

While I’m not going to pretend that I didn’t have a good time with this game, I’m also not going to pretend I didn’t have a good time because it was Breath of the Wild again. The two heavily and maliciously advertised regions in the game are either complete gimmicks or just straight up boring and a slog to get through. The dungeons are on average much better than the Divine Beasts except for the water dungeon because of the cognitive dissonance of it being in the sky and the last dungeon in the game (not the final area) is straight up just a tech demo. The story is just a slightly altered repeat of its predecessor with a whole new cast you’re never going to meet. The gameplay is “better” especially since it fixes the main issue with weapons that people had in the last game. The game however shamelessly lies to you in order to make ends meet. No like seriously. In the numbers and the world itself. I have a whole 13.3 MB documents of me going on a rant about this game I can share if requested.

I’m saying this as a diehard fan of this franchise and it infuriates me that this is what we got. Can’t in good faith recommend this to any Zelda veteran. If it was in the $30 -$40 price range this game would be an well deserved 9-10 /10 but if you’re going to list yourself as a higher than average AAA game at $70 you better have the bite to back up that bark and this game just doesn’t have that.

items.quote:
Es una estafa. Es un DLC de BOTW. Es exactamente igual. Tenes que buscar a Zelda y ayudar a las 4 tribus, vaya casualidad... igual que BOTW. Encima los 4 templos son EXACTAMENTE IGUALES. Constan de activar 4 o 5 interruptores (ya ni recuerdo de lo aburrido que era y lo faciles que eran los templos. Puedo llegar a entender que los santuarios al ser muchos no tengan tanta imaginacion (que igualmente... parecen pensados para nenes de 5 años), pero los templos principales ponele un poco mas de esfuerzo...), los 4 tienen la misma trama (escuchan voces, te muestran el enemigo final, le peleas, se va, haces los 4 o 5 interruptores, escuchan voces, enemigo final (FACILISIMOS TODOS, excepto el tiburon... pero eso es porque tu acompañante es medio bobi, por decirlo de una manera cariñosa), escuchan voces de nuevo y en todos te cuentan exactamente la misma historia solo que cambiando las tribus... A veces se torna insoportablemente lento (aldea onana por decir un ejemplo). El clan Yiga, una vez que tenes la primera pelea, despues va a ser el resto igual... vas al lugar donde esta, peleas, se escapa y lo tenes que seguir al siguiente lugar...
Aparecen nuevas mecanicas, se utilizan mas los materiales (sarcasmo) reemplazaron habilidades por otras simplemente: Antes tenias bombas? ahora podes acoplar armas a piedras para romper paredes, pero adivina que... vas a tener que ocupar espacio en armas que su unico fin es romper piedras (y que encima se suelen romper antes de que te abras camino, por lo que tenes que cargar muchas). Podes hacer mas fuertes las armas? es exactamente igual que BOTW solo que ahora estan oxidadas las armas y es NECESARIO usar materiales para mejorarlas (SUPER FORZADO). Usas materiales para crear flechas de fuego, hielo, etc? Es lo mismo que en BOTW solo que te daban directamente las flechas (SUPER FORZADO). Las camaras del juego dejan mucho que desear (lentas de moverse, muchas veces dificultan lo que queres hacer, sobre todo con el iman), los acompañantes en los templos son insufribles y te ocupan espacio de camara todo el tiempo (sobre todo el goron... dios mio, tuve que googlear como hacer el templo de fuego rapido porque no lo soportaba mas de acompañante).

Muy poca imaginacion y abuso al consumidor porque BOTW fue tan bueno que sabian que ibamos a comprar TOTK.

AHH es verdad, utilizaron el mismo motor grafico y las mismas canciones que el anterior. Mismos enemigos con la adhesión de un par nuevos nada mas... En serio estuvieron 5 años desarrollandolo? o los que hayan estado, me da igual... cómo es que les importan tan poco los consumidores?

PD: No pongo una nota mas baja porque pude montar a Zelda que era mi sueño; y podes entrar a gerudo sin ser un femboy (me saco el sombrero)

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
Warning: Minor Spoilers

Not only has Tears Of The Kingdom surpassed its predecessor, but, in my eyes, it has surpassed every other game in history regarding its quality in practically every aspect of the game.

First and foremost the gameplay is incredible, there is a real sense of immersive and engaging exploration no matter where you find yourself in Hyrule. Many criticise the fact that it reuses the map from Botw, however to call it a reused map is harsh at best. Not only are there many additions to the bulk of Hyrule (such as the temples, new enemies with new fortresses and a multitude of caves) but there are two new unique sections; the depths and the sky islands. Although both can at times become a bit repetitive, the vast amount of new and mysterious locations, alongside the diversity of new monsters makes both a pleasure to explore. The combat, while unchanged, is nonetheless thrilling, and is refreshed by the addition of new enemies such as the Gleeok and Froxes. Alongside this, one of the most hated aspects of Botw combat has been somewhat mended, and of course I am referring to weapon durability. The ability of fuse, while not completely solving breaking weapons, still allows new and powerful weapons to be remade fairly easily and adds a creative aspect to Link’s weapon stash. Furthermore, the addition of ultra hand has been praised by many for adding further creativity to the game, and giving the player more freedom to explore Hyrule as they wish.

Secondly, I highly praise Nintendo for the enthralling story provided. Throughout the entirety of the game I found myself constantly looking forward to encountering a Geoglyph, as practically every time I was treated with a captivating or thrilling scene regarding Hyrule’s past. The addition of new characters such as Rauru, Mineru and Sonia, alongside the return of our favourite characters such as Link, Zelda and the man the myth the Legend Sidon, has added a both familiar and emotional side to the story. I must take a moment to talk about the return of the Demon King himself: Ganondorf. My hat goes off to Nintendo for the addition of such a menacing, intimidating and epic character. He is the driving force for the entire story and the final boss battle against him is inconceivably incredible, by far the best boss battle I have ever done. I do recognise that there are some convenient tying up of loose ends post game, however the ending is ultimately wholesome and rewarding.

Finally, the progression of the game is also very well executed. While some argue that they fall short of the quality of old Zelda dungeons, the 5 (technically 6) temples are all a blast to complete. They all have a much needed uniqueness about them and there are a couple of brilliant boss battles, but ultimately they are a nice change from the reparative nature of Botw’s divine beasts.

I apologise for the lengthy review, however I just wanted to reveal and reiterate what an incredible game this is. If you haven’t already picked it up I highly suggest that you do. 

Easily the best game I have ever played: 

10/10

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
Tears of the Kingdom is a really fun game. It's new mechanics, bosses, and parts of it's story are really cool, fun and entertaining. It does have it's downsides however. For one, the sage's powers are not as good as the champion's from Breath of the Wild. 

A good example of this is Riju's power, where a lightning bolt strikes wherever an arrow hits. This does work well on paper, but when they executed it, it was difficult to activate not only because of the other sages, but also because Riju used melee combat only. So to use a range move with a melee fighter who always runs towards the enemy make things pretty annoying. 

Another thing that annoys me is the lack of connection between BotW and Totk. While playing the game, I only really got some references to Mipha, but not to the others. And sure, I can get their weapons, but I'm not sure that 100% counts. What also annoyed me is how there's no way to transfer items from Breath of the Wild to Tears of the Kingdom. It would've been cool if we had some way of doing so, like going into the house at Hateno Village and finding them.

The final thing I wanna mention that annoys me are the droprates of certain items. I spent at least 3 days hunting Ice-Breath Lizafros because I needed their tails in order to upgrade my Desert Voe Trousers, and out of the 39 (Yes I counted them) Ice-Breath Lizafros that I could find, only 6 of them actually dropped a tail.

However looking past those small annoyances, I did enjoy the game. Weapons when fused last longer than normal weapons in Breath of the Wild, which is incredible because it actually feels like I'm using a weapon for more than 5 seconds. Back in Breath of the Wild, a normal Lynel fight use to take at least 3-5 of my weapons. In Tears of the Kingdom, not so much. Sure, sometimes my weapons break during those fights, but it's not as short as it is in Breath of the Wild.

Overall, I do love this game. I recommend you try it.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
This game is great, but it kind of annoys me to see so many reviewers call it a masterpiece. It does have plenty of flaws.
The good:
-Fun, interesting, unique gameplay. The mechanics are almost the same as Breath of the Wild and that's okay, it was a great game too. The main new mechanic is the building of zonai devices. It felt out of place to and it can be really janky, but it is fun once you get the hang of it.
-The story is a bit more cohesive and interesting and a less generic than your typical Zelda game.
-Exploration is top notch. There's so much to do and look at. So much interesting stuff happening. If you see something unusual in the distance, there's a 90% chance something worth checking out awaits.
-Copy and paste most of what was great about Breath of the Wild.
The bad:
-The starting price of $70.
-Enemies are overpowered. Most enemies can kill you in two or three hits. As you gain more hearts and better armor, the smaller enemies will take a little longer to kill you, but the large enemies still kill you in two or three hits. The exception is the bosses. They're actually pretty easy.
-The unskippable and partly skippable cutscenes you have to watch over and over again. Nintendo, STOP IT.
-The unskippable and slowly scrolling dialog. Nintendo STOP IT!
-Platforming. Zelda games need to fix the way Link jumps or stop having platforming. It is tedious and its not fun. He jumps much like you would in real life. Not very high, not very far, and forward without any ability to correct in midair. That's fine except in real life you're not jumping across 5,000 foot high chasms and you're not controlling your movement with an analog stick.
-The companions are awful. They get in the way, they sabotage you, their powers are either underwhelming or useless.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
I completed the game last week after playing for 3 weeks nonstop, got all shrines and sidequests complete (but not seeds/armors upgrades/photos), just like I did with BOTW.

I'm a huge Zelda fan and completed all games in the series, I had the same opinion as I often read about BOTW, it's an amazing open world game filled with content, but a very poor Zelda game. I hate how people praised the "you can do anything in any order" part, that's exactly what makes it stray away from the formula. You are supposed to unlock unique items in a specific order to gain abilities and unlock harder sections of the map, that's what makes a Zelda game a Zelda game. I also hated like most the weapon destruction, and the stamina/climbing that while it helped with locomotion, it was painfully slow and long and padded the playtime with annoying moments doing nothing but waiting. Nevertheless, I enjoyed pretty much everything else.

Come TOTK, I initially got a bad first impression when they showcased it with a construction aspect. I hate construction games, if I wanted to do so I would play Sim Cities or Minecraft or online survival games, not a single player Action RPG. But fortunately, it ended up being not bad at all. The fact that pieces are limited and break after a while restrict it to smaller sets and mostly to get past a simple puzzle, so I actually liked it.

The new paragliding mechanic is great for faster locomotion too, but completely rendered the horses useless (never used one in the whole game except for quests). It also brings the same negative aspect as climbing that half of the gameplay time is spent teleporting to a tower, launching up and gliding toward the objective point, which get long and repetitively annoying with nothing happening.

As far as the rest of gameplay elements go, there's absolutely nothing else, it's a complete copy/paste of the same game with no redeeming qualities that can explain the long development time, same engine, same graphics, same combats, same quest structure. I think they trolled us by making the weapons "decayed" and even easier to break. Instead of making longer more complex shrines, they just added even more!

The depths seemed cool at first, and I loved the Yoga questline in there, but after it was done I realized it was just an empty mess. It's 10x bigger than it should have been and there's absolutely no reward for lighting it up, it seems like a big afterthought they didn't complete. "Just make the players run along in the dark for hours with no goal".

But the part that disappointed me the most are the side quests. In every previous Zelda games, including BOTW, they were at least interesting to complete, always with some funny or clever aspects. In TOTK, they are just fillers, they are boring collectible or just going back and forth to places. I feel like they forced themselves to place references to every character of other games, even if it didn't fit in the story and the world, they put them there as an afterthought to fill in a checklist of references.

That said, I still loved my time playing it, but I absolutely cannot agree with people saying it's the game of the year, it's just a downgrade to this marvelous series. I seriously hope Nintendo scraps the concept and reboots anew again for the next title.
items.author: Dunge

items.quote:
Tears of the Kingdom brings so many fun mechanics to the already great foundation that Breath of the Wild created. The depths added hours of fun exploration and although there are not too many sky islands, the rewards I found up there were always a joy to obtain. The dungeons are a huge improvement over its predecessor but once again the shrines can start to feel a little repetitive and tedious after some time.

Being able to visit this version of Hyrule one more time and experience the changes to the overworld and characters left me constantly smiling. The only reason this score is an 8 for me instead of higher is parts of the game do feel very similar to BOTW which in this case is both a positive and a negative.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
I had a pretty well thought out review prepared for TotK to justify giving it such a middling score, but through the power of the internet and Error 403, that review has, much like my hopes for this game, been cast into the pits of despair, consigned to endless oblivion.

In short, as I've already wasted enough time talking about a game I can't seem to get myself to enjoy:

-Ultrahand is a novelty that quickly becomes tedious and jerks me out of any immersion I may have felt regarding the exploration and story elements.

-The same can be said for weapon durabilty and the new "feature" of using Link's power of "Gorilla Glue" to attach random bits and bobs to a stick, turning it into a new-and-improved stick. I didn't have a problem with this in BotW, though it was annoying at times; the new mechanic just means I'm forced to spend hours of my finite existence attaching things to other things; it's like I'm trapped in a nightmare where I'm forced to make children's crafts and then go out into the wide-open (and sort of boring, to be honest) world and beat something to death with them.

-I can't comment on the story, as I haven't been able to force myself to endure the water-boarding that is the new "Super Zelda Maker" building mechanic long enough to get to anything approaching an interesting story hook. Notwithstanding this, I've received mixed signals on the story from other reviews: some swear it's the best thing since sliced bread; others say it's boring and full of contrivances and retconning of lore from other games. I sincerely hope the latter isn't true, but given i've already been spoiled on a few major plot points and was pretty unimpressed with them, I don't have high hopes.

All in all, this game might be acceptable if it didn't have the Legend of Zelda or Breath of the Wild names attached to it, with all of the expectations that entails. But as a Zelda game, it's not at all what I expected, and sets a precedent for the series that I have no interest in. Here's hoping this is an anomaly and not a guidepost for how the games are going to be moving forward. The saying goes that a bad craftsman blames his tools. But I came here to go on an adventure and save a princess, not build 500 rafts and bridges.

items.quote: Such a great game, took everything they had built upon in previous 3d Zelda games and fused them all together. I enjoyed the story very much, new and different elements but many familiar trops to the Zelda franchise. There are so many fresh new mechanics that are fleshed out and feel like they have always been there. There are so many ways to play this game, whether you play Tears of the Kingdom in the traditional Zelda manner, or you go for more creative methods to complete whatever you task yourself at the time, there's no limit to the possibilities and you won't be disappointed. You'll most likely lose track of how much time you spend exploring the world. The amount of content in the game is ridiculous and it has a very high replayability. As of now I've spent about 400 hours in the game.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
A continuação direta de The Legend of Zelda: Breath of The Wild de 2017, teve seu retorno de forma conturbada, Link e Zelda se depararam com uma entidade antiga, denominada Demon King (Rei Demônio) no subsolo do Castelo de Hyrule, e após um confronto direto dos nossos heróis com o inimigo, o destino de Link e de Hyrule se tornaram caóticos.

Sobre o jogo em si, foi reaproveitado da versão de 2017, tanto em gráficos, quanto em jogabilidade e inimigos, porém, a Nintendo aprimorou a forma em que lutamos contra os nossos inimigos com as novas habilidades adquiridas por Link com o seu novo braço concedido por Rauru (Primeiro Rei de Hyrule).

Com estas novas habilidades, o jogo ficou totalmente mais intuitivo para os jogadores atingirem seus objetivos, quer antingir o topo de uma montanha? ao invés de subir por completo e demorar minutos até chegar ao topo, monte uma construção que possa levá-lo em segundos, isso foi uma sacada genial por parte da Nintendo.

A história por outro lado, foi na minha visão muito mais bem construida que o jogo de 2017, apresentando figuras mais conhecidas da franquia The Legend of Zelda, como por exemplo o Ganondorf.

De forma geral, o jogo teve tudo de superior ao Breath of The Wild, usando a criatividade do jogador a todo momento, porém ao meu ver, foi uma construção mais fácil de se fazer e menos inovadora por reaproveitar grande parte dos recursos do jogo anterior.

Nota final: 9/10

Recomendado!

items.quote:
Improves on Breath of the Wild in every way. Nintendo managed to re-use BOTW's map and still made the game and world feel fresh and exciting.

The new powers (that replace BOTW's) are all fun to use, and can provide a huge variety of ways to finish the game's various shrines and other puzzles. There's so much to discover, as well as rediscover from BOTW. The dungeon design is a big step up over BOTW, enemies and bosses are more varied, and the overall game is such a blast to get absolutely lost in.

This is what open world games should aspire to be.

items.quote:
Tears of the Kingdom is a really tricky situation. Does it deserve a higher rating than BotW because there's clearly just more to do? Or does it deserve a lower rating because every criticism of BotW hasn't been addressed at all? (Weapons break, rain interrupts climbing, and ridiculous/nonexistent rewards for exploring)
Due to the increased price, I'd go for the latter, which always deserves a lower rating if it doesn't come with a noteworthy increase in quality. This is just a standalone expansion after all. A decent one, but not $70 decent.
items.author: GabuYenn

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
While much of the game felt like I was replaying Breath of the Wild, it really started to grow on me the more I played. The world is largely the same as in BotW but with some significant modifications for the better. I didn't care too much for the sky, but rather enjoyed exploring the depths, which is eerie and huge. The shrines were much fun and focused on solving puzzles. The weapon durability is annoying, however, it does encourage you to use different weapons, which can be fun when using the fuse ability to modify them. Ultra hand is cool and adds a whole new dimension to the gameplay; it's not a gimmick and is quite useful.

The game doesn't have traditional temples, but I do feel that it makes up for that by having an interesting world full of different regions, numerous shrines and also wells, which is a new staple for the series. Traversal is quite good even without the need to use a horse. The horses are difficult to control anyway.

The game offers a LOT of side adventures, side quests and shrine quests. I generally focused on the main game but did one or two dozen side quests here and there. This is the first ever main Zelda game to feature voice acting. The voice acting is okay; nothing special. As usual, Link doesn't talk.

The graphics are slightly improved over BotW but not by much. The game may appear graphically outdated compared to other games on other platforms, but overall it looks fine and nice. The frame rate could be better though.

Many assets from BotW are indeed recycled for TotK, such as musical pieces, certain characters, flora and fauna, items and enemies. I really think that this, and the fact that there are no traditional temples, is ultimately what prevents me from giving this game a 10. But it makes up for it by having plenty of new things like the depths, the sky, new abilities, etc.

items.quote:
The Legend of Zelda is my favorite game series. I played all games since Ocarina of Time and enjoyed all of them. This game is unbelievably big with a crazy amount of things to see and do, but that is also the reason i dont give it a higher score. Everything feels so overwhelming, and was very confused on why i had to do a lot of seemingly unrelated side quests in order to progress in the main story. I feel like they are called side quests for a reason, they shouldnt be mandatory to finish a game.
For example: After i got beat by Ganon in my first fight with him i come to realize is was missing a sage (Mineru). Now i need to do a quests that you can find in Kakariko village in order to progress, if you dont get the hint like i did you will search the map for mutiple hours before you know you had to go to kakariko village and do this quest. Now after you do try doing this quests you need to do a lot of side quests in order to get some purah tablet functions (scanner+) so you can find the electric clothing pieces. After hours of tedious boring quests you can finally find the sixth sage and you are ready to fight Ganon.. But in order to know where Ganon is, you got to, you guessed it, do more side missions with the researcher girl in the lookout posts. These are some of the most boring missions ever, where you follow statues for hours in the underground, while you just want to finish the game and kill Ganon. After all these hours of doing boring side quests, you come to realize Ganon was just under hyrule castly.. Why all the sidetracking just to get this information?

items.quote: Tears of the Kingdom is a true sequel to Breath of the Wild. It expands the original in every way possible. The mechanics are deeper and more ambitious. There are more missions and collectibles. The map now has an underground, caves and the sky to explore besides a new version of the old surface. Its story, although still anchored in the past, presents stronger characters and more elaborate moments. TotK is also a technical masterpiece achieving a level of interactivity that few games could, even in PS5 and Xbox. Having said that, Tears' gargantuan horizon of possibilities tends to engage the player in completing shores and collect-a-ton, hurting what we expect of the impact and epicness of a mainline Zelda title.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote: This game was incredible. While it uses the same map, this game was in a unique position as a sequel because you get to see the world change and how it’s adapted. The new additions were great with the caves, sky islands, and depths. The sky islands could be more expansive but they’re still impressive. The story is leaps and bounds better than botw and while the voice acting is still meh, it’s much improved from the last game and Matt Mercer kills it as Ganondorf. The actors for Sonia and rarue were also pretty good. The music was incredible. Every new track fits the setting perfectly and the boss tracks are bangers. The regional missions are cool and the temples are far better than the divine beasts. They aren’t traditional dungeons but each one has a unique theme and the puzzles are still fun. The new abilities are also great and add so much to the progression of the game. The durability was made even more fun because of the fuse ability, and being able to make vehicles with untrahand in so cool. The physics are insane and the fact that this game runs on a switch is a testament to the incredible game design. The final boss is the best finale in the Zelda series and looks and plays fantastically. One of the best games of all time, no question.

items.quote:
he Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom is the sequel to the critically acclaimed Breath of the Wild. It takes place a few years after the events of the first game, and sees Link and Zelda once again on a quest to save Hyrule from a great evil.

The game builds on the open-ended gameplay of Breath of the Wild, giving players even more freedom to explore the world and solve puzzles. There are also new features, such as the ability to craft weapons and vehicles, which add to the game's depth and replayability.

The story of Tears of the Kingdom is more complex and engaging than the first game. There are more characters to meet, and the stakes are higher. The game also features some memorable boss battles that will test your skills.

Overall, The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom is a worthy sequel to Breath of the Wild. It is a must-play for fans of the series, and it is sure to please newcomers as well.

Here are some of the pros and cons of the game:

Pros:

Open-ended gameplay
New features, such as crafting and vehicle building
Complex and engaging story
Memorable boss battles
Beautiful graphics
Excellent music
Cons:

Some technical issues, such as occasional framerate drops
Some puzzles can be too difficult
The story can be slow-paced at times
Overall, I would highly recommend The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom to fans of the series and open-world games in general. It is a truly epic adventure that is sure to keep you entertained for hours on end.

items.quote: I had been looking forward to this game since I finished Breath of the Wild five years ago.  I had sky high expectations and was slightly worried I wouldn't enjoy Tears of the Kingdom as much as I did my Breath of the Wild playthrough, partially because I had just spent 200 hours on Elden Ring and my standards for an open world game have gone through the roof.  Tears of the Kingdom easily met and surpassed my expectations.  From building contraptions to doing every shrine in the game, this was one of the best experiences I've had with a video game in my entire life.

items.quote:
三个月，140+小时，当结局CG终于播放完时，我发出了一声混杂着感慨、满足和放松的叹息。

和前作《旷野之息》相比，这一作多了一段比较充实的前置剧情，既交代了事件起因，也能很好地表现出人物性格和关系。尤其是和前作时隔六年，能再次看到熟悉的塞尔达公主、观察到她与林克之间熟悉的互动细节，让我相当感动。

可惜这段互动没能持续几分钟。之后魔王苏醒，天地巨变，公主不知所踪。这次再醒来，就是在「新手村」初始空岛上了。这里给我留下的第一印象，就是截然不同的氛围和生态：金黄色的树木和草地，白色的断壁残垣，厚重青铜色的管家魔像和守卫魔像。这些色彩组合在一起，配上一早一晚准时响起的空旷钟声，使得空岛虽然古旧荒凉，却依然不失圣洁之感。

落到地面之后，熟悉的海拉鲁大地在眼前展开。尽管主要地形和前作相比没发生太大的变化，但是在原来的基础上多出来的错综复杂的洞窟，让地图呈现出了新的样貌。再加上到处都有从天而降或是嵌进山体的巨石，配合上时间倒转、通天术等技能，可以实现人物高度的迅速上升。前作里攀爬起来费时费力的高山，现在不再能成为探索的阻碍，反而成了随时随地发现新惊喜的藏宝地。

因此，拖慢前进步伐的不再是纯粹的障碍，而是玩家自发的探索欲望，这是我认为《王国之泪》的一个高明之处。更不用提到处散落的各种各样的支线、怪物，以及需要护送的呀哈哈，总有那么几样东西会让你忍不住停下脚步。我一开始是要做什么事来着？我都玩了两个小时了为什么还在做别的事？——在海拉鲁大地上向着新的目的地进发时，这样的体验几乎成为了常态，却不会给我留下负面感受，我想就是这个原因。

当然对于前期孑然一身的林克来讲，更高密度的内容也意味着更高的难度。缺装备、武器差、血量上限低，都降低了战斗的容错率。好在刚刚落地就能迅速抵达的「监视堡垒」是自己人的地方，这里的NPC会永远给予林克支持：床可以免费使用，灶台的火永远燃着，有一些基础的武器可以随时取用，还有数名已经是老朋友的研究员，会为林克指明探索的方向。这些细节都为玩家快速过渡到中期提供了支持。

在前作《旷野之息》中，认识林克的NPC寥寥无几，所能提供的帮助和指引也比较粗略，从始至终林克都是自由而孤独地四处探索。而到了《王国之泪》，从最开始的「监视堡垒」，我就能明显地感觉到大量的信任、敬意与支持，被这些真诚的情感包围的感觉让我相当满足。

这种支持感在我遇到第一个讨伐队任务时达到了顶峰。跟着讨伐队一起向怪物营地冲锋时，那种「我不是一个人在战斗」的真切感受差点让我哭出来（好吧，我承认前作里实在是太孤独了）。

大小和地上区域一样的地底世界，再次给了我不小的震撼，因为这几乎意味着多了一倍的内容量。我也终于明白了为什么有人说「《旷野之息》是《王国之泪》的demo」——相比之下，本作的大地图由一个变为了天空、大地、地底三个，内容更丰富，情节塑造也更饱满，难免给人留下完成度更高的印象。

items.quote:
If you haven't played BOTW, then this game might be better for you. In my opinion, the fun of exploration is massively reduced by the ability to fly. I found myself shooting up from the towers and flying to any waypoint I needed to, because it was easier than running or horsing about.
The bosses are also not great, especially the Water temple boss. It's so incredibly pathetic. The desert one is okay, and I really liked the Ice one. Got so bored after the water temple that I never got to the fire one.
This game feels like an expansion for BOTW, that took 6 years. Yeah, some of the stuff they added is cool. But it's not as refined and polished as many diehard fans seem to imply. While this is far from a bad game, I cannot recommend it at full price.

items.quote:
Nobody's here to engage with an extensive academic paper, so I'll swiftly address this matter in a straightforward manner, encompassing both positive and negative aspects (with the negatives referring to elements I personally didn't favor but that don't significantly impact the overall evaluation).

The Positive:

If you were a fan of "Breath of the Wild," you'll be pleased to learn that all its mechanics have essentially made a return.
The fresh runes introduced are, for the most part, quite impressive and inject innovation into exploration.
While the revamped overworld isn't flawless, I'm willing to acknowledge that the enhancements exceeded my initial expectations.
The new areas introduced are captivating. Exploring caves and underground spaces is particularly enjoyable.
The game's designated dungeons, often referred to as such, represent a notable enhancement over the Divine Beasts in the previous installment.
The Negative:

If there were elements of "Breath of the Wild" that didn't resonate with you, you might be disheartened to discover that every fundamental gameplay mechanic from the previous game has made a reappearance.
Employing the Ultrahand for construction purposes (its other functions are acceptable) is frustrating. Straying from the intended construction projects often leads to inefficacy. Opting to construct bridges seems to be the most effective and amusing choice.
Occasionally, it's evident that certain parts of the game world weren't designed with your expanded toolkit in mind. This is likely due to the fact that these areas were developed with the tools available in the original "Breath of the Wild."
The narrative is notably subpar. While following the same minimalist narrative approach as its predecessor, it suffers from an even weaker script. Ganondorf's character deserved a more compelling treatment.
The Less Favorable Aspects:

Irrespective of the game's nomenclature for them, these "dungeons" don't conform to the traditional Zelda fan's expectations. The Divine Beasts weren't outright disappointing, yet they left me yearning for a more gratifying experience. The dungeons in this installment are essentially refined versions of the Divine Beasts, albeit lacking the unique control mechanics. Nonetheless, they do represent an overall improvement.
The removal of whistle-sprinting is regrettable. Although it was an unintended glitch that needed addressing, it was undeniably practical for swift navigation. The absence of a replacement for this mechanic is a missed opportunity.
To summarize, the game is undeniably enjoyable. However, considering the six-year development span and the $70 price point, it's a substantial request for what the final product ultimately delivers. It often feels more akin to an extensive DLC rather than a genuine sequel—not in terms of scale, as the game certainly boasts an expansive scope, but rather in terms of its fundamental essence.

items.quote: One of the most enjoyable games I have ever played.  Loved the cell shade art style and the lively villages full of interesting people.  The open world is full of interest.  Many times I set out to do something, but found myself wandering around from place to place, checking out various things that caught my interest in the open world and completely forgot about my original objective.  Controls are smooth and precise, but takes a while to get a grip on how to use all of the abilities.  I was probably 30hrs in before I was comfortably using the abilities, and still messed it up from time to time throughout the game.  The user interface was much improved over Breath of the Wild, but could have used further quality of life enhancements such as remembering favorites for crafting a fire with pine cone or only showing relevant items for cooking, fusing to arrows instead of managing large menus with each item every time.  Music is amazing.  It really enhanced the feel of each place you visit and gave each space an identity.  Performance was not bad as well, I didn't experience any crashes or major glitches.  The only issue I had performance-wise was the frame rate dropped quite a bit, especially in areas with lots of vegetation.  Overall, could not recommend this game enough whether you are a open world sandbox fan, or want to try one out for the first time.  Anyone who liked Breath of the Wild should be pleased with all that was built on top of it with Tears of the Kingdom.

items.quote: The way this game took the story and world left off from breath of the wild and turned it into something so fresh yet nostalgic is nothing short of phenomenal.  They created a story that expands outside of that in the previous game in all directions.  The world is deeply enriched not only on the surface with many new shrines, caves, and updated towns, but fully new maps in the sky and depth.  One of the most impressive things of all is the physics mechanics build for this game.  Zonai devices such as hover stones, stakes, fans, springs, and so much more help the player have the freedom to explore the world and make creations all their own.

Tears of the Kingdom es el mejor videojuego que he jugado nunca. Aunque ya hace bastante que me lo he pasado, quería sentirme preparado para hacerle una reseña aquí en condiciones y un ensayo más profundo. Aquí solo tocaré la superficie del título, pero es que la superficie ya es una obra maestra. Empecemos.

Breath of The Wild es una obra maestra y estábamos asustados cuando se anunció la secuela. Tener miedo era de tontos. Este juego supera en todos y cada uno de sus aspectos a Breath of The Wild. El brazo derecho es la tabla sheikah pero si la hubiese creado Da vinci junto a Eiji Aonuma. Por favor que buena que es. Voy a hablar de cada poder en individual.

La ultramano: permite agarrar objetos y juntarlos mediante un pegamento mágico. Básicamente, el imán pero todavía mejor. El gran incentivo de la ultramano son los vehículos y gracias a los artilugios zonnan, podemos crear auténticas maravillas de la ingeniería moderna. Esto sumado a un sin fin  de interacciones más, hacen de esta una de las mejores mecánicas que he visto nunca en un videojuego.

De las mejores porque está la combinación. Ahora tus armas pueden fusionarse con cualquier cosa. Sí, cualquier cosa. Esto soluciona uno de los mayores problemas de BotW, la vulnerabilidad de tus armas, ya que aporta más daño y más resistencia. Además, dependiendo de los objetos, el arma, escudo o flecha puede tener diferentes interacciones, dando lugar a un combate mucho más estratégico y amplio.

El retroceso es como el paralizador pero al revés. Cualquier objeto (menos enemigos) que se haya desplazado, puedes devolverlo a su sitio anterior. A nivel técnico es una locura, pero a nivel jugable es todavía mejor. Expande todavía más el combate y crea un montón de puzzles que se sienten distintos aun teniendo una mecánica en común.

La infiltración es el más simple de todos. Básicamente, sirve para colarte en techos o estructuras que tengas encima, pero es muy útil y se usa mucho a lo largo del mapa.

Hablando del mapa, este es doble I (inmenso e increíble). Inmenso porque son 3 mapas: las islas, unos territorios no conectados entre sí con algunos acertijos muy interesantes, la superficie, porque es muy parecido al mapa de Breath of The Wild, y el subsuelo, porque se siente muy distinto al resto y la exploración es muy distinta y estratégica. Increíble porque está genial diseñado en las 3 zonas.

Los templos son un muy buen acercamiento a los Zeldas de Nintendo 64, pero se quedan lejos de ser como estos. Supongo que porque indican los puntos a los que tienes que ir, en vez de dejar tú que explores. Las boss fights son muy superiores a las de Breath of The Wild, teniendo una variedad inmensa de bosses y usando todas mecánicas que has estado usando en ese reino a la perfección.

Audiovisualmente, es una obra de arte. El estilo artístico es de los mejores que he visto en un videojuego y la OST tiene algún temita que se te ponen los pelos de punta incluso si eres calvo. Mis 10 en este aspecto.

Aunque he visto muchas críticas a la historia, a mí me ha gustado mucho. Me parece muy superior en la manera de contarse (aunque sí que es verdad que a veces puede llegar a parecer que ni se toma en serio), en lo que cuenta, en personajes y en todo en general.

En resumen, juega Tears of the Kingdom. Es que si no has jugado al juego no sé ni que haces leyendo estas palabras. Me da igual que sean 70 pavines, te lo compras y no te va a decpecionar. Tan recomendado que si no lo juegas me enfado.

items.quote: I really hope that Tears of the Kingdom is the future of this series.  Don’t get me wrong, I still love the older, classic games, but I can’t help but feel that this formula is it.  The amount to explore and discover is staggering.  With the inclusion of the Zonai devices, there seems to be no limit on how to go about discovering this vast open world.  I’ve been playing it since release and still have not done everything.  I love the return of proper dungeons, but I do wish there was more of them.  My one gripe is what I feel as a clunky system to fuse weapons, shield, arrows and the like.  You have to scroll through a slew of items in the quick menu to find the one thing you want to fuse, or find it in the main menu, hold it, drop it in game, then select the option to fuse.  Doesn’t feel intuitive.  But! Other than that, this game is damn masterpiece, and very much a Game of the Year contender for me!

items.quote:
If you love BOTW you will love this game. If you haven't loved it, you won't love TOTK. I think it's a great game with wonderful game design choices and many things to do. There are caves, the sky islands, the depth, bosses in the open world, good side quests... Especially the enemy variety was increased. You can now be more creative than in BOTW. Outfits are easier to get and you can change their Colours. Fuse and Ultrahand are easy to use and provide many options. No playthrough is the same.
The story might be the best Zelda Story of all time. I didn't expect Nintendo to tell such an emotional story in one of their games. Especially the cutscenes with Ganondorf are spectacular.

items.quote: Everything I ever really wanted, I liked Botw but to me it had some big flaws, lack of real dungeons, lower enemy and boss variety, and at times kinda empty map. Not only do you get dungeons back, you get caves which are basically mini dungeons in their own right, same with shrines. The reintroduction of like-likes, gibdos, and what are basically floor masters, and basically kargaroks, really round out the enemy variety, the reintroduction of gleeoks and gohma is awesome and all the other new bosses are real fun as well, story was great, I often felt more rewarded when completing a side quest as the rewards were often more worthwhile, side quests were much more memorable than Botw. It’s just better in every way, and then you add on, sky island and depth exploration, as well as weapon fusion and building and there’s no doubt in my mind that this game is a masterpiece.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
This game was a lot more BOTW. If you liked BOTW, you'll like TOTK. I unfortunately did not have the creativity or the energy for getting much out of the building system, nor does the game really require you to use the system much. The game fix any of the issues I had with BOTW, mainly the weapons breaking after 1-2 kills.

The voice acting is just as bad as in BOTW for most characters (Rauraru and Zelda specifically), made worse by there being even more voice acting. There's no standout performances, but Tulin and Ganondorf are acceptable.

Performance was abysmal overall. Using the God Hand power would drop my Switch to what felt like 15-20 fps. The fire temple also ran at about 10 fps the entire time.

Was it awful? No. Was it my GOTY? Not remotely.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
I'm genuinely disappointed with this new entry. I had high hopes for it and was brimming with excitement, especially after falling in love with BOTW. However, what I encountered was a mere replica with an excessive emphasis on farming and grinding, making it less enjoyable. While I do commend the level of freedom granted for weapon crafting and vehicles, the mechanics underlying these aspects feel remarkably cumbersome. It always seems like you're awkwardly piecing things together, and the game doesn't become engaging until you finally acquire a few batteries. Yet, the process of obtaining them is far from enjoyable, requiring three Zonaite just to obtain a single Crystallized Charge, and an astonishing 300 for a mere one-third battery upgrade. The substantial time investment in this farming aspect is simply not fun.

Furthermore, performance issues plague the entire game, which is surprising given that many reviewers appear to overlook these problems. It's evident that these issues, if present in any other game, would have garnered severe criticism. When i looked for advice online i found some players telling me to "Set TV output in the System Menu to 480p. and only play on docked mode"... I am no graphic **** by any means I swear to you but I suppose I can expect more than that in 2023, especially after they raised their prices specifically for TOTK knowing we will buy it anyway. Adding to my disappointment, the game's structure mirrors that of BOTW precisely. The novelty that once existed seems to have dissipated, likely contributing to my disenchantment. The puzzle rooms also got stale pretty quickly this time around. While I'm still intrigued by the future of the Zelda series, I earnestly hope for an innovation that delivers a completely fresh experience this time around. However, considering the overwhelming success of TOTK, I'm wary of setting my expectations too high. I realized that my score might seem harsh but ultimately the game was disappointing to me to the point where I almost dropped it before the very end so here we are!
items.author: Fate21X

items.quote:
It takes everything that made BOTW good and makes it better. It's combination of puzzles, open-world sandbox experimentation, exploration and freedom in approach in everything from traversal to combat makes it one of the best and most unique gaming experiences you could have.

It would take other game developers a very long time to even try to imitate what Nintendo has done with this game. One of the greats.
items.author: Phoenix93

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
Depois de "Breath of the Wild" ter criado um alicerce perfeito, "Tears of the Kingdom" chegou para alavancar a franquia aos céus - e, dessa vez, literalmente!!

"Tears of the Kingdom" conseguiu replicar e expandir a sensação de inovação e descoberta de um mundo novo fornecida por seu antecessor. Com um enredo simples porém extremamente envolvente, o jogo nos apresenta uma das histórias mais sentimentais da franquia junto de uma jogabilidade extremamente inovadora e que nos permite passar horas e horas em Hyrule fazendo jus ao lema "it's science, ****!"

Entretanto, há de se ressaltar que, em alguns momentos, Tears of the Kingdom não difere muito de BotW, especialmente na parte introdutória do jogo, o que pode frustar e/ou afastar jogadores que já jogaram o título anterior. Ainda assim, Tears of the Kingdom faz parte do roll de jogos categorizados como "must-play" do Nintendo Switch!!

items.quote: Once again Nintendo has done its thing again, it has given us a practically complete game, a game to beat would be somewhat unfair, it is the first time that I have seen so many mechanics and new experiences that it is amazing, be careful, I do not declare myself a fan of Zelda but after playing this title I have completely fallen in love, for me it is the game of the year 2023... for several reasons. The soundtracks, the cinematics, how you connect with the characters, the new abilities like ultra-hand, combining weapons with objects whether they are consumable or not, infiltrating through the ceilings, that's wild. Ganon's new appearance seems majestic, worthy of a king, it reminds me a lot of Ocarina of Time. I think the symbology is one of the strongest points of this game and once again this title deserves the game of the year.

items.quote: This game brings me inner peace and a sense of calmness. It’s honestly ****. The fact that you can have so much enjoyment from just exploring and gathering resources without ever feeling rushed to finish the story. But when you do get around to completing main quest lines, oh boy do they deliver on some intense backstory. BOTW was lacking story but TOTK has a phenomenal story that steers you, emotionally, in just the right way. And of course the insane build mechanics they’ve implemented just takes this game to a whole other level of entertainment! It’s like a game within a game and inside those games, there’s another! But they all blend so well together and it never feels like it’s trying too hard to be something other than a Zelda game. It’s the perfect Zelda game.

items.quote: Why was everyone in this game so HOT it literally made no sense. Zelda, Link, Ganondorf, Sidon, Mineru, Sonia, Rauru, Paya, Urbosa, and Tauro were all major baddie alert status. And yeah all of Link's abilities were super fun to use and the exploration was fun and everything was good. The story was a lot better than in botw, although it still wasn't the main focus yk? The main boss fights and dungeons also felt like a major upgrade from botw, although the dungeon puzzles still weren't to the level of something like A Link to the Past, so I would've liked some more interesting puzzles. Considering that link had such interesting abilities in this game, they could have had Portal level puzzles if they wanted to tbh, although I guess they wanted to keep the game accessible to younger kids too. Another thing I would've liked is if they had more challenging shrines and also some more spots in the overworld to really use Link's abilities. Like mainly I would just use recall every once in a wall to throw a boulder back at an enemy or I might use ultrahand to make the world's most simplistic boat, but i feel like they could've had more interesting puzzles link might just come across in the environment that would make the player think a bit further outside of the box. But that's a pretty minor complaint, and it was overall a really really enjoyable experience.

items.quote: Tears of the kingdom is quite literally just breath of the wild, with a few clunky gimicks that barely improve the experience. If you never played BOTW, then this is a great game for you, but if you're like me and have 400+ hours in BOTW, this is NOT the game for you. The map is hardly any different, the depths and sky islands are boring and empty, the new enemies rarely appear and when they do are nothing but annoying, the fuse system is alright but kinda uneccesary and makes the issues of clinging on to certain weapons and never using them even worse, ultrahand is both overpowered but annoying, and the shrines can easily be cheesed. Zonai technology isn't available enough, so i end up walking around for hours trying to find a control stick so i can actually build something. There are a heap of other problems, including the story. The story is already not the best, but the entire plot twist got ruined for me because I watched the memory from lurelin village which quite literally directly showed me that zelda was a puppet. All the memories about immortal dragons and then finding a dragon with zeldas hair and the master sword sticking out of it spoiled that. Anyways im sick of writing this review, i have even more issues with the game but overall it was a very unenjoyable experience, especially coming from BOTW.
items.author: Soupymittenz

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

family.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

title.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

game.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
This game is fantastic. The scope of it is absurd: so many times I couldn't believe just how big it was and how I could see so far into the distance and know I could go there without a single loadtime. Then there is the fact that there is a whole area of the same size underground and a much smaller but still great area in the sky and is becomes almost unbelievable that this is running on the Switch.
Still, that is not without its problems, as the game is 30 fps with constant framedrops, which is a shame, as it really detracts from the experience.
Nevertheless, this is a world worth exploring. There are NPCs and field bosses and interesting quests at every turn. You 100% get sidetracked all the time because there is just so much to do.
The physics are impressive. So many shrines rely on you solving puzzles and they can all be "cheated" by exploiting the game's systems, it is wild and sparks creativity.
The building mechanic is quite impressive as well, but I have to say a lot of the time it is difficult to make it work. A lot of the contraptions are kinda wonky and it takes a long time to build something more stable, especially without autobuild just doing it for you out of the schematics.
The companion mechanic is kinda bad, it seems half-baked. Activating their abilities should be tied to a menu, instead of you having to turn the camera to find and run all the way to them whilemashing A, and they should help out in combat more. I don't know if it's a better mechanic than the abilities in BotW.
The story is a bit mixed. It's good, but very repeated from BotW and due to the non-linear aspect of the game, you kinda have the same experience(story-wise) whenever you do a regional main quest, the characters don't react to the things you already know, which is especially jarring after you learn about what happened to Zelda.
**** ending is superb. From the moment the Ganondorf fight starts to the end, it is just out of this world. Both great in scope but also a tearjerker. I have not felt this good after a game ending in a long while.
All in all, a fantastic game, worth of all the praise and will be remembered as one of the great titles of the Switch.

items.quote:
王泪基于旷野之息开发，新鲜感却不减反增。
王泪地图在垂直维度上有了大提升，多了天上和地下两片大地图，可探索元素更加丰富。地面地图多了的很多洞窟，有一种法环开荒的感觉，天上是不连续的空岛，地下则是黑暗待点亮的地底。天上、地面、地下是三种完全不同的探索体验。借助下坠和花式升空方式，三者又能无缝跨越地探索。
王泪的神庙比旷野之息的更好玩，两者的神庙都是围绕林克的基础能力设计的。旷野之息围绕希卡能力：炸弹、磁铁、时停、制冰；王泪围绕左纳乌能力：究极手、倒转乾坤、通天术。两者有很大不同，益于究极手，王泪的丰富度更高一筹。
王泪的战斗也更好玩了。除了新增的敌人、巡逻小队、据点，还有瘴气、粘土、铁轨、黑暗等等新的环境要素，余料建造和究极手更是直接丰富了战斗体验。余料建造和究极手是一体两面，都是把东西拼起来，只不过余料建造会把拼接的物体变小。其中，新的环境要素和究极手，也是探索体验得以革新的基础。
和前作相比，王泪给了我完全不同的游玩体验。从游玩体验上将，这就是一款新作，而不是旷野之息2。先写这么多。

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
What most people see:
-A fun crafting system that utilizes layers of exploration and fusing combinations.
-Giant open world, filled to the brim with things to do, characters to talk to, and landmarks to see.
-A calming atmosphere with great narrative moments that expand and explore Hyrule.

What I see:
-A monotonous, over complicated inventory full of **** you will never need. Making every single action in this game an absolute chore to execute. Fusing items not only looks ridiculous but just adds another unnecessary step to a combat system that was already pretty annoying to begin with.
-I hate when games go "open world", because i know it's just going to be me looking at the back of my character just running around 60% of the time. No game has done it quite like Bethesda, and unfortunately Tears of the Kingdom falls into more of those "Open World" pitfalls, even more so than it's predecessor. Granted there is more "content" in this game, but it's mindless and unfulfilling busy work. The lack of NPC's and proper story telling really hold this game back for me.
-Don't @ me but the soundtrack felt...lazy, not atmospheric. There is a difference. Windwaker is atmospheric, OoT is atmospheric. Probably a subjective opinion but mine nonetheless.

I see people giving this game good scores and still pointing out these flaws about the game, IMO the score you give should reflect your full opinion. I think this game is a 7 in all honesty. It's the most "fine" I've ever felt about a Zelda game. I am a little bias in saying i hate this formula, but i at least enjoyed Breath of the Wild. There was something about the original that didn't feel overwhelming and encouraged me to collect cool items and talk to people. The world felt more alive, and featured a FAR MORE interesting cast.

items.quote: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom is a truly remarkable sequel to Breath of the Wild. Rather than sticking to the same old formula, this game takes the series to new heights by blending creativity, innovation, and the strengths of its predecessor. With fresh gameplay mechanics, an expanded world, a good storyline, and improved technical performance, Tears of the Kingdom stands as a monumental achievement. This title has the potential to contend for Game of the Year, and despite minor imperfections, it surpasses the already high standards set by its predecessor. The level of hype is justified, and anyone with the opportunity to play it should do so without delay. Beyond its numerous accomplishments, including a rich open world and expert level design, the true beauty of Tears of the Kingdom lies in its ability to reflect the player's intuition and creativity. The game's brilliance isn't just a solitary experience; it shines brightly alongside the player, creating a Legend that will undoubtedly be remembered as a pinnacle in gaming. In essence, The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom is a remarkable achievement, deftly building upon the strengths and weaknesses of its predecessor to deliver an immersive and inventive open-world adventure that's not to be missed.

reviewedProduct.title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

items.quote:
Why did I give 6?
well, because Tears of the Kingodm is an 8 video game, however in the context of a the legend of zelda it is already a lot if it takes a 3, for this doing an average it comes out a six.
the video game is fun, has immediate gameplay that does not tire and is capable of making you spend hundreds of hours of fun, since facing enemies and completing the various mini-games on the map is extremely fun due to the dynamism of the gameplay. thanks to the ultrahand it is possible to build incredible things and thanks to the compositor the crafting of weapons is fast and immediate. so what's wrong? well since building vehicles and completing minigames isn't the reason a person buys a Zelda game this game for me was a complete bust. Zelda as always is all about exploration and a sense of discovery, and when you fail this point you have failed the entire game. Let's start with recycling. The asset recycling in this game is disgraceful, and I honestly don't understand why people defend this, despite the fact that the game still cost 70 bucks. And stop comparing it to majora's mask which only recycled npc assets. Finding again enemies, weapons, fauna, flora and clothes from the previous game was a huge disappointment. especially when most of the enemies are bokobli, grublin, lizalfos, octorot and lynel again. also the Yigas appear in the exact same way. The map of the sky, so advertised by Nintendo, is nothing more than a group of tiny islands and copy pasted with the same puzzle. the exploration of the sky was disappointing because I find it extremely boring to explore to always find the same things. the underground may look cool at first but then it turns out to be nothing more than a wasteland with only one biome and with ridiculously repeated enemies. it has only 2 structures and it repeats them all over the map giving the feeling of exploring a procedural environment. Hyrule has remained the same, and no, I don't consider moving shrines and korooks to be a different map. I honestly found it extremely boring to explore a map on which I had already spent hundreds of hours botw. the only satisfaction was given by the caves, even if many of them are similar and a bit boring. Since Nintendo has decided that all the same rooms with a puzzle inside can very well replace the Dungeons, also in this game we have only 4 small dungeons (the castle of Hyrule has remained the same as that of botw). The temples in this game are none other than the divine beasts but dressed differently. Honestly I'm sick of this game being compared to the first zelda for NES, since the only thing they have in common is that they have an open map. in Zelda 1 dungeons were essential, just as it was essential to explore to get items without which you could not complete the game. in totk everything is made to be Optional, the really useful things are only given to you at the beginning, everything else is just finding useless things just for completion. if you don't care about Zelda or what it has been to date this game will be perfect for you, otherwise it was a complete disappointment.
